lesson.name: Unit 3: Part 2: Focus on the Students

page.title: Overview
page.contents:
English language acquisition can be enhanced by activities that are relevant to learners’ lives, goals, and interests.

Learning experiences should promote  

  • autonomy,  

  • choice,

  • collaboration,

  • meaningful communication, and

  • metacognitive awareness.   

To Go Deeper


Metacognitive awareness is the practice of thinking about one’s own thinking and learning. This involves paying attention to learning strategies and using more of the effective strategies and fewer of the ineffective ones. Effective instruction teaches learning strategies explicitly.

page.title: Focus on the Students
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_U3_Slide-22.mp3

Audio transcript


Digital literacy activities support both English language learning and the development of digital literacy skills, including finding and evaluating information online. Adult English language learners bring their own beliefs about thinking, language, and learning strategies to digital tasks. These beliefs influence the way that ELLs approach and accomplish digital tasks. When planning instructional activities, teachers can think about their own beliefs about thinking, language, and learning strategies and predict that their ELL students’ beliefs will be different.

Adult ELLs can develop digital literacy skills to learn independently and have more choices in their own learning. Effective digital literacy activities use collaboration, facilitating meaningful, goal ­directed communication as learners work together to complete the activity. The skills required for working in teams are part of the cultural knowledge required for English language learners’ success in college and careers (as demonstrated in Wrigley, 2015). Effective digital literacy instruction promotes metacognitive awareness and explicitly teaches a variety of strategies. In general, all students, including English language learners are motivated and engaged in learning to use technology in their education.

Digital literacy activities support

  • autonomy,  

  • choice,

  • collaboration,

  • meaningful communication,  

  • metacognitive awareness, and    

  • student motivation and engagement.

page.title: Focus on the Students 2
page.contents:
Topic- or theme-­based, problem-based, or project-­based approaches are easily enhanced with digital literacy. In these approaches, integrated digital literacy activities are supported in a variety of ways:

  • A purpose for learning is established.

  • Students have developed the background knowledge to bring to the activity.

  • The language (vocabulary and grammar) that students encounter is more likely to be familiar.

  • Relevant and just-­in-­time learning is related to accomplishing the activity.

Examples of Internet searches that can be integrated into lessons or units are described below.

Lower Level

(more searching, less evaluating)

Topic: In a unit on geography/countries, What time is it in [name of country]?

Topic: In a unit on local business, What are the addresses and phone numbers of local stores?

Project: Which supermarket is the cheapest (Gaer, 1998)?

Intermediate Level

(searching and some evaluating)

Topic: In a unit on finance, find the nearest branch of various banks and credit unions.

Project: How can you buy a car?

Topic: In a unit on medicine, find the locations and hours of the nearest pharmacies.

Project: Make a presentation on chronic health conditions (Trupin, 2010).

Advanced Level

(searching with a focus on evaluating)

Topic: In a unit on consumerism, compare features and prices of an object or service.

Problem: What to do about conflicting medical information.

Project: On a vacation to Vancouver, BC, find three sightseeing locations that your family or friends would like.

page.title: Overview of an Integration Approach
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_U3_Slide-24.mp3

Audio transcript


Integrating digital literacy skill-building activities into existing lessons and units is better than teaching the skills in isolation. Here is an overview of the basic principles of this approach. First, identify an Internet search that is appropriate for the lesson or unit. Second, in the design of the activity, position technology as a tool to complete the project rather than the goal itself. For example, in a low-level adult English language acquisition class, you might have a unit on food and shopping. It would be appropriate to add an Internet search activity in which the students identify the supermarket that is the cheapest for food items that the students have indicated are important to them. Design the activity so that the students can follow the same process for a search in each unit to provide many opportunities for practice. A set of activities that can serve as a guide to designing the activity for your class, represented by the mnemonic S-E-A-R-C-H, will be described in a little bit. Finally, as the need arises, teach mini-lessons that are needed to complete the activity. The mini-lessons can be on vocabulary or grammar needed for the topic or on a digital skill such as how to identify an advertisement in a search result. A list of helpful online resources is included at the end of this unit.

Basic principles:

  • Identify a related Internet search activity for each unit.

  • Position technology as a tool to complete the project or answer the question, not the goal itself.

  • Design the Internet search activity to be similar for each unit to provide many opportunities for practice with increasing independence.

  • Teach mini-lessons on the digital skills on a just­-in-­time basis, as they are needed, to accomplish the task. (A list of resources is at the end of this unit, and resources are embedded throughout.)

page.title: Overview of an Integration Approach 2
page.contents:
When integrating a new digital activity into your class, find out what students already know and do.

Make an “I can __” list. Depending on the level of your class, present this activity as a whole class discussion or as an information grid activity in which students ask one another. Be sure to generate ideas from students and make your own list.

I can use the Internet to . . .

On my computer

On my phone

On another device

Find a translation of an English word.

      

Select a class that I want to take.

      

Find an address or a map.

      

Communicate with my child’s teacher or school.

      

Find recipes.

      

Find out how to spell a new word.

      

Compare prices on items I want to buy.

      

Get an answer to a medical question.

      

Other: _________________________

page.title: Finding Information: Searching Online
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_U3_Slide-26.mp3

Audio transcript


Henry created a mnemonic device to remember the process for finding and evaluating information online. It is S–E–A–R–C–H, search. The “S” is for “set a purpose for searching.” The “E” is for “employ effective search strategies.” The “A” is for “analyze search engine results.” The “R” is for “read critically and synthesize information.” The “C” is for “cite your sources.” The “H” is for the question, “How successful was your search?” Searching online is likely to be a new type of task for your adult English language learning students, and some of the steps involved make cultural and linguistic assumptions, including the idea that taking a critical perspective is appropriate.

To begin learning the new skill of searching, start with a topic and language that are very familiar to your adult English language learning students. Especially with low-level ELLs, consider starting with a search that the students already know the answer to. When teaching a new skill, the language used and the topic should be well known so that the students’ focus is on the new skill: how to find and evaluate information online.

In the article “SEARCHing for an Answer: The Critical Role of New Literacies While Reading on the Internet,” the author (Henry, 2006) presents a mnemonic device for remembering the strategies to use when searching for information. The mnemonic is to help both students and teachers remember the strategies.

page.title: S E A R C H Set a purpose for searching
page.contents:
Help students learn to narrow a topic by identifying a purpose or goal for searching. The purpose or goal will closely relate to the topic, problem, or project that is the focus of the unit. You might use guiding questions, such as

  • What do I need to know to accomplish this task?

  • What will I do with this information?

You might encourage the students to start with an inquiry, such as

  • Where is the nearest bank?

  • What is asthma?

  • When is the end of the school year at my child’s school?

page.title: S E A R C H Employ effective search strategies
page.contents:
Listen to audio: 

ELL_Mod2_U3_Slide-28.mp3

Audio transcript


Employing effective search strategies is an important skill in finding and evaluating information online. Just like with prereading strategies, effective search strategies consistently compare what is already known to the information found. Adult ELLs can’t rely on only nuances of language and must also use their funds of knowledge in their search strategies. For example, in a low-level class on the topic of shopping or consumerism, an appropriate search would be to find the prices of things that the students already buy at stores that they are familiar with. By using information that is already familiar (the cost of the item) and language that is already familiar (the name of the item, the name of the stores, prices), the students can focus on the new task-the Internet search. In the structure of the activity, be sure to model the strategy of comparing information that is discovered to what the students already know. This works toward the skill of critically evaluating information found online.

Similar to pre­reading strategies, effective online search strategies start with what students already know. This is helpful because it

  • reviews vocabulary that might be encountered,
  • supports purpose in the search,
  • reminds students of prior knowledge that new information can be compared against, and
  • models an effective strategy.

 One strategy to help students think about what they know is to use a KWL Chart, shown below. 

What I Know

What I Want to Know

What I Learned

What I usually pay for [favorite item] ______

What does [favorite item] cost at stores nearby?

Store 1: ____

Store 2: ____

Store 3: ____

How does this compare with what I usually pay?

page.title: Exploration Activity: Administrators
page.contents:
Here are four different resources about searching on the Internet that can help you know more about teaching students to do effective online searches. Look at one of these sources—or all of them. Bookmark the useful resources on your social bookmarking site, or make a note of them.

Think about the information and resources as they relate to what teachers need to do. Think about the professional development that could support integrating Internet searching instruction into your programs. 

All About Online Search and Google Search Tips

Read more


Two short modules (be sure to watch the videos!) by GCFLearnFree.org: http://www.gcflearnfree.org/ digitalskills/searchbetter

Teach Your Students to Google

 

Read more


An article on searching with Google specifically: http://www.eschoolnews.com/ 2014/11/24/google-like-pro-678/

Effective Internet Searching

 

Read more


A blog on slightly more advanced search tips: http://techtipsforteachers.weebly.com/ blog/effective-internet-searching

Find information

 

Read more


A website with more advanced information and literacy strategies (be sure to read the linked sections and watch the videos): http://www.learnthenet.com/learn-to-search/

page.contents:

Think about the information and resources to determine how they may be useful to you and your students.

page.title: Reflective Activity
page.contents:
Consider the questions related to the option that you selected. 

What resource(s) did you select?

How might each resource be useful to you in your instructional planning?

How could each resource be helpful to use with students (or not)?

page.title: Things to Think About
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_U3_Slide-36.mp3

Audio transcript


As you move forward think about two things. First, think about what you have learned about strategies that are important in finding and evaluating information online and how you might incorporate them into a search activity that your students might do. Second, think about the resources that you have explored and whether or not you can use any of these resources with your students—many of the resources have visual and auditory elements that make them more effective than plain text for adult ELLs.

As you move forward, think about the following questions:

  • What are the strategies that I have learned so far?

  • What resources will be useful with my adult English language learning students?

page.title: S E A R C H Analyze search engine results
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_U3_Slide-37.mp3

Audio transcript


New and inexperienced Internet searchers may be tempted to try to read every word of the search results summary or select the first several results to read carefully, without questioning the selection. Neither is an effective strategy. Adult English language learners may come from educational, linguistic, or cultural backgrounds where analyzing information with a critical perspective is not common.

Analyzing the search engine results is part of the critical thinking skills used in searching for information on the Internet. At a minimum, students need to be able to recognize results that are advertisements, fast facts, and results in different formats, such as maps. Some English language learners may find it helpful to look at results in image form to pick out results for closer reading. Model how you analyze search engine results by talking through your responses to the results of a search on a topic that is well known to you and to your students, using language that they know well. The point is to model the analysis, not to teach new language in the process. You want to reduce barriers to the students’ understanding. Additional helpful information can be found in GCFLearnFree.org® Google Search Tips. Analyzing search engine results takes considerable practice, so it is important to integrate online searching as a routine activity in every unit. More advanced English language learners might enjoy the A Google a Day site, which has a new "puzzle" each day that can be solved by conducting a Google search.

New and inexperienced Internet searchers may be tempted to try to read every word of the search results summary or select the first several results to read carefully, without questioning the selection.

Adult ELLs need to be able to recognize results that are

  • advertisements or sponsored content;

  • fast facts; and

  • results in different formats, such as maps.

Some English language learners may find it helpful to look at results in image form to pick out results for closer reading.   

Additional helpful information can be found in GCFLearnFree.org® Google Search Tips.

More advanced English language learners might enjoy the A Google a Day site, which has a new "puzzle" each day that can be solved by conducting a Google search.

page.title: Reading a Web Page
page.contents:
GCFLearnFree.org® http://www.gcflearnfree.org/

Once several search results have been selected, it is time for a close reading of those resources.

English language learners may initially find it difficult to identify website content in a busy web page with advertisements and navigation taking up a good portion of the page.   

Watch the 3 minute video from GCFLearnFree.org as it explains the different parts of a web page and where the content is.

To read the full module go to https://www.gcflearnfree.org/searchbetter/

page.title: S E A R C H Read critically and synthesize information
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_U3_Slide-39.mp3

Audio transcript


Information on the Internet may be posted by people with an intent to inform, persuade, sell, and demonstrate, as well as to mislead. Anyone can put anything online. Because this is true, critical reading is an essential strategy when searching for information on the Internet. Critical reading involves being a healthy skeptic and answering key questions about the information and its sources in four key areas: relevance, accuracy, bias or perspective, and reliability. Kathy Schrock has created a reproducible with key questions in these areas; see the image on the right side of your screen). The depth to which you can pursue these questions depends on the level of your students and their experience with the Internet, among other things. Since critical evaluation is unfamiliar to many adult English language learners, it is important to model it carefully and often as well as to discuss it explicitly. Critical reading of information is a skill that takes practice.

The Five W's of Web Site Evaluation

Who
Who wrote the pages and are they an expert?
Is a biography of the author included?
How can I find out more about the author?

What
What does the author say is the purpose of the site?
What else might the author have in mind for the site?
What makes the site easy to use?
What information is included and does this information differ from other sites?

When
When was the site create?
When was the site last updated?

Where
Where does the information come from?
Where can I look to find out more about the sponsor of the site?

Why
Why is this information useful for my purpose?
Why should I use the information?
Why is this page better than another?

©2001-2009 Kathy Schrock.
Page may be reproduced for classroom use.
Bookmark created by Kim Simonis.

Information on the Internet may be posted by people with an intent to inform, persuade, sell, and demonstrate, as well as to mislead. Anyone can put anything online. Because this is true, critical reading is an essential strategy when searching for information on the Internet.

Critical reading involves being a healthy skeptic and answering key questions about the information and its sources in four key areas:

  • relevance,

  • accuracy,

  • bias or perspective, and

  • reliability.

Kathy Schrock has created a reproducible, shown to the right, with key questions in these areas.

Table adapted from Kathy Schrock’s Guide to Everything “Critical Evaluation of Information” at http://www.schrockguide.net/critical-evaluation.html

page.title: Read Critically and Synthesize Information: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Here are two resources that have valuable information about reading critically and synthesizing information. Both provide information on this topic that is readily adaptable to adult English language learners. The Edutopia Blog by Julie Coiro is written about adolescents, and the GCFLearnFree.org module is created for adult learners. Both address how to ask critical questions, which is so important (and difficult) for adult ELLs to learn.

Edutopia Blog

Although the Edutopia blog is written about adolescents, it is applicable to adult English language learners as well.

Read more


“Teaching Adolescents How To Evaluate the Quality of Online Information” (Coiro, 2014) http://www.edutopia.org/blog/evaluating-quality-of-online-info-julie-coiro

GCFLearnFree.org Module

This GCFLearnFree.org module is part of the Search Better series.

Read more


How to judge online information: http://www.gcflearnfree.org/digitalskills/searchbetter/judging-online-information

page.title: S E A R C H Cite your source
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_U3_Slide-43.mp3

Audio transcript


When students organize and communicate information, it is important for them to cite their sources. At every level, students can be exposed to the ideas of intellectual property and questions about “Whose idea is this?” Individual authorship is a concept embedded in culture and varies widely across the world. When integrating finding and evaluating information online into your adult English language acquisition classes, talk about the concept when reading a website. Discuss how ideas about the ownership of ideas and words vary across the world. To learn more about citing sources, intellectual property, and fair use, along with resources for students, see the GCFLearnFree.org® module on copyright and fair use linked from this page.

When students organize and communicate information, it is important for them to cite their sources. At every level, students can be exposed to the ideas of intellectual property and questions about “Whose idea is this?”

To learn more about citing sources, intellectual property, and fair use, along with resources for students, see the GCFLearnFree.org® module on copyright and fair use.

page.title: S E A R C H How successful was your search?
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_U3_Slide-44.mp3

Audio transcript


Part of the search process is to evaluate the success of the search. If the search yields the information that is needed, the search is finished. If not, the search needs to be revised. This is a cycle of search, evaluate, and search again until the information is found. A second and equally important part of evaluating the success of the search is about learning. Second language acquisition activities should support metacognitive awareness by asking students to think about their own learning. In the case of Internet searching activities, discuss the things that were easy, the things that were hard, and what helped when the activity was challenging. Have students share ideas with one another. In cases where students share a non-English language, it is very appropriate to use their non-English language in discussions about learning.

The search cycle.

  • Information found? Search is finished.

  • Information still needed? Revise search and try again.

Learning from the search process.

  • What was easy?

  • What was difficult?

  • When the search was challenging, what helped?

Discussions in proficient languages are appropriate for this purpose.

page.title: Internet Search Activity
page.contents:
Design an Internet search activity that is appropriate for your students and that can be incorporated at least once into every unit throughout the class.

Within each unit, the search should align closely with the vocabulary, content, and purpose of the unit.

Design the activity to go through the cycle of SEARCH strategies, at least as far as is appropriate for your students. Students’ English language literacy and basic digital literacy skills will play a role in how much evaluation is possible, but even very low level students can start with searches to answer basic questions.   

Use mini­-lessons for strategic direct teaching. Resources are listed below.  

  • PowerPoint presentations on website basics designed for adult learners.

  • Short video courses about searching online, along with a downloadable PDF handout.

    • What Is a Search Engine? (1:30)

    • Basic Search (3:00)

    • Ads in Search Results (:45)

    • Search Review (1:45)

  • REEP technology curriculum that integrates technology lessons with work­-related lesson plans.

page.title: Reflective Activity
page.contents:
Questions for Reflection

What would your Internet search activity look like?

Identify a class into which you would like to integrate an Internet search activity.

List three to four lessons or units that you can add the Internet search activity to.

For each lesson or unit, what is the topic of the search? (For example: On a vacation to Vancouver, BC, find three sightseeing locations that your family or friends would like.)

Briefly describe each element in SEARCH that you would include in the Internet activity for this class.

How will you ensure that each Internet search activity will give the students increasing independence?

Share your thoughts and your lesson activity with your Community of Practice, or with your colleagues on the LINCS discussion forum.

page.title: Activity for Administrators
page.contents:
Questions for Reflection

What supports are required for teachers to be able to integrate Internet search activities into their classrooms? Support can take many forms, including:

  • technical support,

  • professional development opportunities,

  • time for planning,

  • available in-class devices,

  • opportunities to collaborate with colleagues, and

  • many more kinds of support.

To Go Deeper


To learn more, read Learning for Life: The Opportunity for Technology To Transform Adult Education.

page.title: Final Thoughts
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_U3_Slide-47.mp3

Audio transcript


There are benefits to starting with one Internet search activity that you can integrate into several units. For one thing, you will have the opportunity to fine-tune the activity so that it works well with your teaching style. For another, your students will become familiar with the structure of the task, and it will seem easy. Once you have become comfortable integrating a search activity into most of your units, consider expanding to integrate another aspect of digital literacy as a regular part of your class. You might go to Unit 2 of this module, called “Information and Communication Technologies for Language Learning,” and select one of the skills: listening, speaking, reading, writing, or vocabulary. Then, create an activity that you can integrate into multiple units in one of your classes. Perhaps you might create an activity that is for students at the same level, but you might also consider a different level that you teach. This would have the advantage of helping you gain experience integrating digital literacy activities at different levels. Continue integrating new digital literacy activities until digital literacy is part of your students’ everyday experience in class—as it is in their lives.

There are benefits to starting with one Internet search activity that you can integrate into several units:

  • You will have the opportunity to fine-tune the activity so that it works well with your teaching style.

  • Your students will become familiar with the structure of the task.

Once you have become comfortable integrating a search activity into most of your units, consider expanding to integrate another aspect of digital literacy as a regular part of your class.

  1. Go to Unit 2 of this module, “Information and Communication Technologies for Language Learning.”

  2. Select “listening,” “speaking,” “reading,” “writing,” or “vocabulary,” and create an activity that you can integrate into multiple units in one of your classes.

Continue integrating new digital literacy activities until digital literacy is part of your students’ everyday experience in class—as it is in their lives.

page.title: Useful Links for Teachers
page.contents:
Resources for Teachers

Here is a list of some useful resources for teachers that have been mentioned in this unit:

Short online multimedia modules by GCF LearnFree.org—“All About Online Search,” “Google Search Tips,” “How to Read a Webpage,” “Judging Online Information,” “Evaluate a Webpage Practice,” and a quiz—at http://www.gcflearnfree.org/digitalskills/searchbetter/

Kathy Schrock’s Guide to Everything “R.I.P.—Respect for Intellectual Property” at http://www.schrockguide.net/intellectual-property.html

Copyright and fair use module by GCF LearnFree.org at http://www.gcflearnfree.org/digitalskills/useinformationcorrectly/copyright-and-fair-use

REEP technology curriculum to integrate technology lessons with work-­related lesson plans at http://aps.schoolwires.com/cms/lib2/VA01000586/Centricity/Domain/74/reepcurriculum/techcurriculum.html

Resources That Can Be Used With Students

Here are some resources that can be useful with students, depending on their level and background:

Digitallearn.org has short video courses about searching online, along with a PDF downloadable handout:

What Is a Search Engine? (1:30)

Basic Search (3:00)

Ads in Search Results (:45)

Search Review (1:45)

Use mini­-lessons for strategic direct teaching. Although developed to fit into a computer literacy class, these presentations can serve as mini-lessons:  

  • PowerPoint presentations on website basics designed for lower level adult learners.

page.title: You have Completed Unit 3
page.contents:
Congratulations!

You Have Completed Unit 3.

Thank you for participating in Unit 3 of Integrating Digital Literacy Into Adult English Language Instruction.

If you would like to learn more about integrating digital literacy into your classes, you can participate in additional units in this module.

  • Unit 1: Digital Literacy in Our lives

  • Unit 2: Information and Communication Technologies for Language Learning

  • Unit 4: Solving Problems in Technology-Rich Environments

A list of further resources is available here (printer-friendly version).

You have reached the end of this lesson.  You may review any of the content in this lesson using the Lesson Menu on the left of the screen.

If you have finished viewing the lesson, (1) click the NEXT button on this screen to indicate completion in your progress tracker.  Then, (2) return to the home page to select your next activity.  Activities you have completed will be checked off in your progress tracker.
